title: Home
text:
Where Waddles Meet Data
Hello, fellow penguin enthusiasts, data nerds, and general lovers of all things quirky! Have you ever found yourself wondering what penguins do when they’re not busy starring in cute movies, slipping on ice, or charming the feathers off us with their tuxedo suits? Welcome to Penguin Data Dive, the ultimate (okay, maybe the only) place for data analysis of our favorite flightless birds and how they interact.


Here at Penguin Data Dive, we take a deep dive (literally, if you count the times we fall into penguin pools) into the lives of penguins. We’re not just talking about counting beaks and tails—we’re into the real nitty-gritty: who’s the fluffiest, who’s got the best dive, and who wears their tuxedo the best.



We’ve got spreadsheets and stats that would make a corporate accountant blush. Want to know how many Gentoo penguins it takes to measure a mile? We can work on that. Curious about how tall an Emperor penguin is when it’s standing on tiptoes? We’ve got that covered. It’s all about finding the fascinating in the mundane—or maybe just finding ways to justify our obsession with penguins.



On this site, you can explore a variety of physical characteristics, including:

Size and Shape: Which penguins are built like linebackers, and which ones are more like ballerinas?
Beaks and Feet: How do those beak shapes influence their eating habits? And who’s got the flashiest feet?




We’re more than just data heads—we’re a community. Join our forums to share your own penguin stories, debate the best penguin movies, and maybe even discuss if chickens can really fit in with penguins (looking at you, Chicken Joe). It’s all in good fun, and it’s all about sharing the penguin love.
So grab your parka and waddle on in. The data is cold, but the analysis is hot!

title: Penguins EDA
section: Penguin Mass vs Bill Length by Species
text:
Penguin Mass vs Bill Length by Species
This scatter plot displays the relationship between the bill length in millimeters (x-axis) and the body mass in grams (y-axis) of three penguin species: Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo, differentiated by color.
The plot shows a clear positive correlation between bill length and body mass. As the bill length increases, body mass tends to increase.
Different penguin species are distinct in terms of their spread and relationships:

Adelie penguins (red) have shorter bills and lighter bodies, with their data points concentrated toward the lower left.
Chinstrap penguins (green) fall between the other two, showing moderate bill lengths and body masses.
Gentoo penguins (blue) exhibit longer bills and heavier body masses, trending towards the upper right.

Overall, this plot indicates that each species has unique body characteristics, with consistent correlations between bill length and body mass.


Code
df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")

title: Penguins EDA
section: Penguin Flipper Length vs Bill Length by Species
text:
Penguin Flipper Length vs Bill Length by Species
This scatter plot visualizes the relationship between bill length in millimeters (x-axis) and flipper length in millimeters (y-axis) among three penguin species: Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo, indicated by distinct colors.
It shows a positive correlation between bill length and flipper length, with clear separations among the three species:

Adelie penguins (red) cluster at the lower-left quadrant, indicating shorter bills and shorter flippers.
Chinstrap penguins (green) occupy a middle position in terms of both bill length and flipper length.
Gentoo penguins (blue) dominate the upper-right quadrant, signifying longer bills and longer flippers.

Each species has a unique trend line, suggesting that flipper length and bill length are positively correlated, but with variations in slope and spread among species. This separation reinforces that each penguin species has distinct morphological characteristics.


Code
df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = flipper_length_mm, color = species)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")

title: Penguins EDA
section: Penguin Bill Depth vs Bill Length by Species
text:
Penguin Bill Depth vs Bill Length by Species
This scatter plot illustrates the relationship between bill length (in millimeters) on the x-axis and bill depth (in millimeters) on the y-axis, for three penguin species: Adelie (red), Chinstrap (green), and Gentoo (blue). Each species is shown with its own color and trend line.
The graph reveals distinct trends among the species, suggesting variations in bill length and bill depth characteristics:

Adelie penguins generally have shorter bills and moderate bill depths. Their data points cluster towards the lower-left portion of the plot, with a positive correlation between bill length and depth.
Chinstrap penguins have a broader spread across bill lengths and depths, clustering in the middle range. Their trend line has a steeper slope compared to Adelie, indicating a stronger relationship between the variables.
Gentoo penguins exhibit the longest bills and lower bill depths, placing their data points on the upper-right side of the plot with a positive correlation.

Overall, the plot suggests a clear relationship between bill length and depth for each species, with variations in range and slope indicating unique characteristics.


Code
df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm, color = species)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")

title: Penguins EDA
section: Penguin Flipper Length vs Mass by Sex in Adelie Penguins
text:
Penguin Flipper Length vs Mass by Sex in Adelie Penguins
This scatter plot explores the relationship between body mass (in grams) on the x-axis and flipper length (in millimeters) on the y-axis for Adelie penguins. The data points are color-coded by sex, with red for females and teal for males. Each category has a trend line and confidence interval.
The graph shows a positive correlation between body mass and flipper length, indicating that heavier penguins tend to have longer flippers.

Female Adelie penguins (red) generally have lower body mass and shorter flippers. Their data points are concentrated in the lower left of the plot, showing a relatively linear relationship.
Male Adelie penguins (teal) tend to be heavier with longer flippers, clustering more towards the upper right. Their trend line has a similar slope to females, suggesting a comparable correlation pattern.

The broader distribution of males suggests greater variability in body mass and flipper length, indicating a wider range of sizes among them. The overlapping confidence intervals highlight some degree of overlap between the sexes, reflecting shared characteristics within Adelie penguins.


Code
adelie %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = body_mass_g, y = flipper_length_mm, color = sex)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")

title: Penguins EDA
section: Penguin Flipper Length vs Mass by Sex in Chinstrap Penguins
text:
Penguin Flipper Length vs Mass by Sex in Chinstrap Penguins
This scatter plot explores the relationship between body mass (in grams) on the x-axis and flipper length (in millimeters) on the y-axis for Chinstrap penguins. The data points are color-coded by sex, with red for females and teal for males. Trend lines with confidence intervals are provided for each sex.
The graph suggests a positive correlation between body mass and flipper length, with differences between males and females:

Female Chinstrap penguins (red) generally have lower body mass and shorter flippers, with data points clustering towards the lower-left area of the plot. The trend line has a mild upward slope, indicating a moderate relationship between body mass and flipper length.
Male Chinstrap penguins (teal) tend to have higher body mass and longer flippers, showing a wider distribution and data points leaning towards the upper-right corner. The steeper slope of their trend line reflects a stronger correlation compared to females.

Overall, males exhibit greater variability in body mass and flipper length, suggesting a broader range of sizes. The overlapping confidence intervals imply some similarities between males and females, though males generally show higher body mass and longer flippers.


Code
chinstrap %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = body_mass_g, y = flipper_length_mm, color = sex)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")

title: Penguins EDA
section: Penguin Flipper Length vs Mass by Sex in Gentoo Penguins
text:
Penguin Flipper Length vs Mass by Sex in Gentoo Penguins
This scatter plot shows the relationship between body mass (in grams) on the x-axis and flipper length (in millimeters) on the y-axis for Gentoo penguins, color-coded by sex: red for females and teal for males. Each sex has a trend line and confidence interval.
The graph indicates a positive correlation between body mass and flipper length, with distinct differences between males and females:

Female Gentoo penguins (red) tend to have lower body mass and shorter flippers, with data points clustering in the lower-left region of the plot. The trend line indicates a positive correlation, but with a relatively gentle slope.
Male Gentoo penguins (teal) generally have higher body mass and longer flippers, exhibiting a broader spread. Their trend line has a steeper slope, suggesting a stronger correlation between body mass and flipper length compared to females.

Overall, males tend to have higher body mass and longer flippers, while females cluster in the lower range. The broader distribution of males suggests a wider range of body mass and flipper length among them. The overlapping confidence intervals suggest that while the sexes have some similarities, the observed trend lines confirm distinct patterns of variation within the Gentoo penguin population.


Code
gentoo %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = body_mass_g, y = flipper_length_mm, color = sex)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")

title: Penguins EDA
text:
Synopsis
The scatter plots of the different penguin species—Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo—demonstrate varying relationships between key morphological features like bill length, body mass, flipper length, and bill depth. Here’s a summary of the similarities and differences among the species:

Similarities
All species exhibit positive correlations between the measured characteristics, suggesting that longer bills generally correspond to heavier body mass or longer flipper length. This pattern is consistent across all scatter plots, indicating that certain physical traits are interrelated among penguins.


Differences

Bill Length vs. Body Mass: In this plot, Gentoo penguins show the longest bills and the highest body mass, while Adelie penguins exhibit shorter bills and lower body mass. Chinstrap penguins lie between these two extremes, indicating a continuum of traits among the species.
Bill Length vs. Flipper Length: Gentoo penguins generally have longer bills and flippers compared to the other species. Adelie penguins cluster at the lower-left, representing shorter bills and flippers. Chinstrap penguins occupy the middle ground, suggesting a balance in these attributes.
Bill Length vs. Bill Depth: Again, Gentoo penguins dominate the upper-right quadrant, with the longest bills and comparatively lower bill depths. Adelie penguins display shorter bills with moderate bill depths, while Chinstrap penguins have a broader range, showing moderate bill lengths and deeper bill depths.
Body Mass vs. Flipper Length (Gender): Across all species, males generally have higher body mass and longer flippers than females. Males also exhibit a wider distribution, indicating greater variability in body mass and flipper length. However, the confidence intervals suggest overlapping characteristics between males and females within each species.

Overall, while there’s a common positive trend between physical traits, each species has unique characteristics, with Gentoo penguins generally being the heaviest and longest, while Adelie penguins tend to be shorter and lighter. Chinstrap penguins consistently occupy the middle ground, exhibiting a blend of traits from the other two species.


Code

title: About
text:
Adelie Penguin
The Adelie penguin (Pygoscelis adeliae) is a classic Antarctic penguin known for its distinctive black and white plumage and white ring surrounding its eye. These penguins are among the smaller species, standing about 46-71 centimeters (18-28 inches) tall. Adelie penguins primarily breed in Antarctica, forming large colonies on rocky coastal areas. Their diet consists mainly of krill, but they also eat small fish and squid. These resilient birds are known for their long migrations across the icy landscapes and their ability to withstand harsh Antarctic winters.







Gentoo Penguin
The Gentoo penguin (Pygoscelis papua) is the third-largest species of penguin, easily recognized by its bright orange beak, white stripe across the head, and peachy-orange feet. They typically grow between 51 and 90 centimeters (20-35 inches) in height. Gentoo penguins have a more extensive distribution, breeding on islands and coastal regions of the sub-Antarctic and Antarctic Peninsula. Their diet is varied, with a focus on krill, small fish, and crustaceans. Gentoo penguins are known for their speed and agility in the water, capable of swimming at high speeds compared to other penguin species.







Chinstrap Penguin
The Chinstrap penguin (Pygoscelis antarcticus) is named for the thin black line that extends across its white chin, resembling a helmet strap. These penguins are similar in size to Adelie penguins, with a height of 68-71 centimeters (27-28 inches). Chinstrap penguins are found in the Antarctic region, mainly on rocky coasts and islands. They are among the most aggressive penguins, particularly during the breeding season. Their diet is heavily based on krill, with occasional small fish. Chinstrap penguins are known for their robust and noisy nature, forming dense colonies during breeding seasons.



Chicken (Not a penguin)




Chicken Joe
Chicken Joe is the classic laid-back surfer dude, who just happens to be a chicken chilling among penguins. Because when you think about who’d fit in at a penguin beach party, your first thought is obviously a bird that usually ends up on a dinner plate. He’s like that one friend who doesn’t realize they’re at the wrong party but still manages to have the best time.
His relationship with penguins? It’s like he’s their zen guru. While the penguins are flapping about competitions and proving who’s the best, Chicken Joe is too busy relaxing in the sun and making friends with everyone in sight. He probably thinks he’s a penguin or something; who knows? But somehow, he gets along with them, probably because he doesn’t care what species anyone is as long as there’s good vibes and some snacks. He’s that guy who makes you wonder if he’s clueless or just a genius at playing it cool.

title: Model
text:
Code
#install.packages("pins")
library(pins)
#install.packages("vetiver")
library(vetiver)
Code
import vetiver
Code
library(reticulate)

out <- py_config()
Code
from pins import board_folder
import pins
from vetiver import vetiver_pin_write
Code
from palmerpenguins import penguins
from pandas import get_dummies
import numpy as np
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
from sklearn import preprocessing
Code
from vetiver import VetiverModel
from vetiver import VetiverAPI

title: Model
text:
Get Data


Code
df = penguins.load_penguins().dropna()

df.head(3)


  species     island  bill_length_mm  ...  body_mass_g     sex  year
0  Adelie  Torgersen            39.1  ...       3750.0    male  2007
1  Adelie  Torgersen            39.5  ...       3800.0  female  2007
2  Adelie  Torgersen            40.3  ...       3250.0  female  2007

[3 rows x 8 columns]

title: Model
text:
Define Model and Fit


Code
X = get_dummies(df[['bill_length_mm', 'species', 'sex']], drop_first = True)
y = df['body_mass_g']

model = LinearRegression().fit(X, y)

title: Model
text:
Get some information


Code
print(f"R^2 {model.score(X,y)}")


R^2 0.8555368759537614


Code
print(f"Intercept {model.intercept_}")


Intercept 2169.269720939398


Code
print(f"Columns {X.columns}")


Columns Index(['bill_length_mm', 'species_Chinstrap', 'species_Gentoo', 'sex_male'], dtype='object')


Code
print(f"Coefficients {model.coef_}")


Coefficients [  32.53688677 -298.76553447 1094.86739145  547.36692408]


Creating the a Vetiver model for the data


Code
v = VetiverModel(model, model_name='penguin_model', prototype_data=X)
 


Establishing a path for the model to be stored


Code
import os
path = 'C:/Users/C25Carter.Potts/OneDrive - afacademy.af.edu/Documents/378_FinalProject/data/model/'
os.makedirs(path, exist_ok=True)


Sending the model to a pin board that allows us to access the model later


Code
# Create a board that allows pickled models
board = pins.board_folder("C:/Users/C25Carter.Potts/OneDrive - afacademy.af.edu/Documents/378_FinalProject/data/model", allow_pickle_read=True)
# Assuming 'v' is your VetiverModel object
# Pin the model to the board
vetiver.vetiver_pin_write(board, v, 'penguin_model')


Allowing pickled models which converts model into byte streams


Code
 
# Create a board that allows pickled models
board = pins.board_folder('data/model', allow_pickle_read=True)
print(board)
